Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Physics and Astrophysics at TCU
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Texas Christian University provides seven undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in atomic, molecular, bio, chemical, and statistical physics, as well as astronomy and planetary science. In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in weekly activities to ensure not only that their research stays on track but that they have an engaging collegial and scholarly experience. By the end of the program, every student will have given a formal presentation about their work; prepared a conference poster and a 10-page report.

This REU site will have a number of broader impacts. The site has a strong plan to recruit undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in physics and astronomy and has at its goal to recruit students from non-research focused institutions. The project plans to be informed by both short term and long term evaluations and is guided by an advisory committee.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Texas Christian University (TCU) Physics and Astronomy REU site received funding to support seven students per year in a ten week REU program in Physics, Biophysics, and Astronomy.  Our primary goal is to enhance the number of students from under-represented groups and students from small, non-research focused colleges into the STEM workforce. The primary focus of REU students during the program involved full-time, hands-on scientific research of a specific research problem with a faculty adviser. Weekly REU Group Meetings are held for both science and professional development workshops.  REU students also participate in fields trip to sites such as the Apache Point and McDonald Observatories, and industry sites of Lockheed Martin and the Comanche Peak Nuclear Power Plant.  The summer experience culminates with a final oral research presentation given by participants to TCU undergraduate and graduate students and faculty.  REU Participants learned from their faculty advisor, their research group mentor, and from each other, and about other areas of physics through weekly science talk and lab tours given by faculty not advising REU students. The REU program included sessions on mentoring, graduate school, industry careers, and scientific communication. 


   Intellectual Merit.  Undergraduates completed an independent research project, gained an appreciation of modern research in physics & astronomy.  They also developed new skills and gained in-depth knowledge in their research area, and were exposed to research in other areas through lab tours, oral presentations, and field trips. The weekly professional development workshops included discussion of graduate education and other careers in science.  Graduate student mentors experienced a valuable learning experience in leadership.  


   Broader Impacts.  REU students completed the program with a greater understanding for modern scientific research, and gained a sense of confidence of their abilities to enable them to pursue a career in STEM.  Students prepare a poster that many present at a regional of nation scientific conference, including the American Physical Society and American Astronomical Society, along with PowerPoint slides after giving an oral presentation at the completion of the program.  During the 2014-2018 grant cycle a total of 29 undergraduates participated in the TCU REU site in Physics & Astronomy, which included 4 Provost-funded students from TCU as NSF REU Participants.  The TCU REU site supports a larger percentage of students from included 70% from under-represented groups in Physics & Astronomy.  During the 2014-2018 grant cycle the TCU REU site students were 53% women, 14% African American, 10% hispanic, and 4% Native American.
